exchanges.user:
So I'm not really sure where to start with this. I've been thinking about reaching out for a while now, kept putting it off. You know how it is.

Work has just been relentless lately. I'm managing a team of people who seem to need something from me every five minutes, and the deadlines keep getting pushed earlier. I had a project due Friday that became due Wednesday, which became due Monday, and by the time Monday rolled around I was basically running on fumes and coffee. My boss says it's temporary, that things will calm down after Q1, but he said that same thing last year around this time. I don't know if I believe him anymore.

The thing is, I'm usually pretty good at handling pressure. I've been doing this work for years. But something feels different this time. Not just tired different, but like... I don't know, disconnected maybe? I finish something and it doesn't feel like anything, like I'm just going through motions. My partner keeps asking if I'm okay and honestly I don't know what to tell them. I'm handling the work fine, everything's fine, but also everything feels like too much all at once, which doesn't quite make sense when I think about it like that.

Anyway. Not sure if this is the kind of thing you work with or if I'm just being dramatic. Figured I'd see what happens.
exchanges.assistant:
I'm glad you reached out, even if it took a while to get here. That hesitation you mentioned? That's real—it can be hard to name what's happening when you're in the middle of it.

**Work pressure and the moving deadlines:**
What you're describing isn't just busy—it's unsustainable. When deadlines keep accelerating and the goalposts shift every quarter, your nervous system doesn't get a chance to reset. You finish something that should feel like relief, but there's no space for that because the next thing is already overdue. That "running on fumes" feeling makes sense. And your skepticism about "things will calm down after Q1"—that's not cynicism, that's pattern recognition. You've seen this cycle before.

**The disconnection:**
This part stands out to me: "I finish something and it doesn't feel like anything." That's not dramatic—that's your mind telling you something important. You can be competent at something and still feel hollow doing it. Those two things can coexist. The fact that you're *handling* the work fine but feeling disconnected isn't a contradiction—it's actually pretty common when you're pushing through without space to feel much of anything. Sometimes our brains protect us from burnout by turning down the volume on everything, good and bad.

**What to tell your partner:**
You said you don't know what to tell them when they ask if you're okay. What if you told them exactly what you told me? "I'm handling the work, but I feel disconnected from it. I don't know if I'm okay or just going through motions." That's honest. It's okay not to have it figured out yet.

This is absolutely the kind of thing worth exploring. You're not being dramatic—you're noticing that something shifted, and that noticing is actually a good sign. It means part of you is still paying attention.

What would help most right now—talking through what's driving this feeling, or figuring out some immediate ways to create a bit more space in your week?

exchanges.assistant:

That moment where they just listened—that wasn't small. You named something hard and uncertain, and they didn't rush to solve it or dismiss it. That "okay, that makes sense" gave you permission to not have it figured out yet. And you felt a little less numb afterward. That's worth noticing. Sometimes disconnection isn't about feeling nothing—it's about feeling alone in what you're feeling. Sharing it can bring some of that feeling back online, even briefly.

**The emergency deliverable:**
And then work yanked you right back into the grind. Another deadline moved up, another fire drill. That whiplash—from a moment of connection with your partner to an emergency all-hands the next morning—makes it hard to hold onto anything that felt good. The numbness came back fast, which makes sense. When the pressure's relentless, your nervous system doesn't stay open for long. It's protecting you.

**"Nothing's going to change unless I actually leave":**
I hear the weight in that thought. It can feel like the only variable you control is whether you stay or go, and since leaving feels impossible right now (the age thing, the uncertainty about finding better), you're stuck. But I want to push back gently on that binary. Leaving isn't the only lever. There might be smaller things worth testing first—boundaries you haven't tried, conversations you haven't had, or even just noticing what specifically drains you versus what doesn't. Not saying those will fix everything, but "stay and suffer" versus "leave and risk worse" isn't the only framing here.

One thing I'm curious about: you mentioned your boss keeps saying things will calm down after Q1, and you don't believe him anymore. Have you ever told him that directly? Not in a confrontational way, but just naming the pattern—"You said that last year and it didn't happen. I need to plan differently this time." Sometimes that conversation shifts something, even if it doesn't change the workload itself.

What landed most from what I said last time—the part about disconnection, or something else?
